body: Unfortunately, this (IMO problematic) behavior is a part of glfw at this time. See https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/40 for rationale, and additional discussion at https://github.com/glfw/glfw/commit/9c20737b60037dbbda5552a45b5af9e1314cc701#commitcomment-4174787 for a current workaround (it's not a perfect solution, but it's the best that can be done given the current glfw behavior).
FWIW, [this](https://github.com/shurcooL/Conception-go/blob/e3686c3923a8759a4b290df0987086d0a90ec5bf/main.go#L5118-L5121) is how I get around the problem for now in my project.
I see, thanks for pointing me to the existing tickets / workarounds.
Not sure I agree with the rationale. on_char is for receiving typed characters just like a text control. The on_key callback can be used to implement any other user-defined behavior if they want.

That was my argument too, see [this comment](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/commit/9c20737b60037dbbda5552a45b5af9e1314cc701#commitcomment-4183744). Unfortunately, I noticed the change only after the PR was long merged and it was too late to point that out.

Using alt and control can sometimes be used to type in alternate characters, so text input should not be blocked universally wen a mod key is held down.

The preferred behavior I would want would be to match that of notepad on windows. If I press a key combination and it results in a character in notepad, then exactly the same character should occur in GLFW. If no character is entered in notepad, then no character should occur in GLFW.

Right... GLFW should emulate the behavior of a text control on whatever platform it is running on.

The on_char callback has no business with modifier flags. That should NOT be added in GLFW 4.

> The preferred behavior I would want would be to match that of notepad on windows. If I press a key combination and it results in a character in notepad, then exactly the same character should occur in GLFW. If no character is entered in notepad, then no character should occur in GLFW.

I agree with that. Except it should do that on Windows/OS X/Linux accordingly. Perhaps this depends on region setting, making it harder and inconsistent.

I've seen Alt as a possible key modifier (i.e. alt+key = results in an alternate character), but never Control or Super. Perhaps it is possible under some configurations, I just haven't seen it.

If the above cannot be implemented within GLFW, then passing modifier flag along with the key input is the only sane alternative that will support all input needs (basically, by pushing the problem upwards for the user application to handle).

I guess you are using a US-keyboard? Because keyboards on other places in the world are different.
For example, many European keyboards have the right Alt-key replaced by Alt-Gr, which is translated to Ctrl+Alt and is needed as a second kind of Shift-key to reach important characters like |, {, [, ], }, @, €, µ, ~, \ and these change from country to country.

why is glfw behavior different for windows and linux when handling key combinations? when i type, for example, ctrl+v on linux both the key and char callbacks get called, but on windows the key callback executes when i press ctrl, and then nothing happens when i press v.
if i switch to handling these key combinations in the key callback there are two problems: on linux i get both the shortcut i want and the char callback called which i don't want. also, with my keyboard GLFW_KEY_Y is 'z', and GLFW_KEY_Z never even arrives.

issue.body:
This is needed to correctly and **_reliably_** distinguish character events from mod+key combinations, due to the change in #40.

See the relevant discussion [here](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/commit/9c20737b60037dbbda5552a45b5af9e1314cc701#commitcomment-4744485) for context of why this is needed, and why there is no possible way to have fully reliable character input with the current API (if there is, I'd love to be corrected).

Before:

```
0000001b to 1 at 3.602: Key 0x0058 Scancode 0x0007 (X) (with super) was pressed
0000001c to 1 at 3.602: Character 0x00000078 (x) input
0000001d to 1 at 3.742: Key 0x0058 Scancode 0x0007 (X) (with super) was released
```

There was no way to reliably ignore the x character input when Cmd+X (shortcut for Cut) is pressed.

After:

```
0000001b to 1 at 3.602: Key 0x0058 Scancode 0x0007 (X) (with super) was pressed
0000001c to 1 at 3.602: Character 0x00000078 (x) (with super) input
0000001d to 1 at 3.742: Key 0x0058 Scancode 0x0007 (X) (with super) was released
```

Now it's easy to ignore the character x from being typed when the user presses Cmd+X.
